data.title: DEBREU RECOGNIZED FOR PURE RESEARCH
data.text:
When Gerard Debreu strolls with close friends and colleagues through a wildlife preserve above the shore of the Pacific Ocean north of San Francisco, the conversation often weaves through the work of Marcel Proust and the music of Saint-Saens.

''Over the years, I have become more and more of a purist,'' he explained today, describing his taste in arts and letters.

That seems only fitting. The French-born economist, now in his 22d year at the University of California at Berkeley, made his mark on the profession 24 years ago in a 114- page monograph filled mostly with elaborate mathematical formulas.

The book, ''Theory of Value: An Axiomatic Analysis of Economic Equlibrium,'' drew enthusiastic reactions from his peers. A reviewer for the American Economic Review, the paragon of economic journals, concluded that ''it would not surprise me if it turned out to be one of the few classics of our period.''

Professor Debreu, now 62 years old, is little known outside the economics profession, but when he was named today as the 1983 recipient of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, his colleagues regarded it as part of the natural course of events. 'An Economist's Economist'

''Gerard Debreu is an economist's economist,'' said Bent Hansen, chairman of the economics department at Berkeley. ''His work is very abstract, very fundamental. But everybody in the profession quotes him and must demonstrate that they know his work.''
